td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: June 10th Saturday. Pass'd our Things over the Port. which is 540yds over a good road (an old Settlemt where a Mr James winter'd 6 years ago is still in being on the left side of the Port.) then entd Sturgeon lake, (in wch we went abt 15m. out of expecting to go by a way (la chemin neuve) which our Guide was unable to find so that we turn'd back on the opposite side of ye lac (which is abt 12m. over) so that being so far wide from the place of our departure 'twas impossible to mark down the proper courses witht turning back to ye Fort, but by the directions I have recd from the Guide, & remarks I have made I don't think there is any difficulty in finding the way)[.] The Co is Wt & SW reckon'd 5 Leags to a pt on Rt near the end of the lac, 2 Is on ye Lt then SWbW abt ½ m. to Port. Embarrassè (here we encamp'd)[.] In the passage from the Fort, to this Portage the Co being abt Wt – keep the So shore on ye Lt crossing the bays (there is no River in the way)[.] If the weather is clear & not too much wind, one may go more large, & by cutting off points, Is &c make the distance much shorter & by keeping the So or Left hand shore always in view, a Person cannot miss ye Portage, which is mark'd down from the last pt mentd[,] the end of the lac being ¼ m. from the Port. Our Canadian Guide having gone with us as far as he knows the way, we have no farther occasion for him, but as he has no Canoe, he is still in our Co – he has been a very good, quiet man, & as he knows the way very well from Pais Plat to Sturgeon lake, we would willingly engage him to winter, so that he may be employ'd as guide hereafter, if there should be Occasion for him. The Indian we met on the 2d inst. has been ever since in our Co & has by no means answer'd to ye Character given by St Germaine : if it had not been for him we should now be in much distress for a Guide, he being the only Indian we have seen since, since we left lac de petite Jour, he knows the way we have taken to day, but is at a loss in the one mentio attempted this morning, he says we have more Port. & more Rapids this way than the other, but on the contrary is much shorter, be it as it will, we must go the way he is capable to Guide us[.] Entd into an Agreemt with him in writing, to the same Purport as that of Pierre Bonneau.
11 Mo Sunday. Got our things over the Port. which is 1010yds long & good road. It blew so hard today, that we were confind to the end of the Port. Paid Pierre Bonneau for Guiding us to Sturgeon lake.

12 Monday. From the Port. entd a lac, cross'd it WbN1½ to a pt on the Rt – passed 2 Islds & a bay on Lt – then WbN1m. to a pt on same side (NB this pt is an excellent place for Poison Dorèe &c.) a bay on Rt & Lt – then NWbW1m. to a narrow stony Channel, pass'd the entrance with difficulty witht discharging, went in the Channel ¾m. then entd a lac, turn'd rod 1st pt on Lt ¼m. then Travers'd SW3m. to a pt a bay on Lt 3 Is on Rt – then SWbS1m.[,] 2 Is on Lt to Portage
